title: Parametric E3D clone Cooling Fan and (double) Part Blower

description.text:
EDIT: superseded by the V3 mount! An OpenSCAD version of the mount listed in the remix's sources. This version has an easily configurable heatsink diameter (heatsinkDiameter) and side fan doubling (doubleSideFan). If you vary the heatsink diameter, there's a parameter for fine-adjusting the clamp's arms length as well (clampLength).
Suggested minimum and maximum parameter as included in the source. The provided STLs are compiled for a 25mm heatsink, with respectively one and two side fans. EDIT 30/04/2016: Customizer fixed.
EDIT 11/01/2016: added the configurability for a z-probe adjustment screw on the side for the Micromake E3D mount, editable via the zProbeScrew and zProbeScrewHeight parameters.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Kossel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: Should be printed in ABS, but works fine in PLA too if you'll always remember to start the heatsink fan whenever you'll heat the hot end. If you fail to do so, PLA will melt slightly and produce sagging of the mount - or worse!
So far my PLA printed mount has given no problems.

title: ModulIX-O - Universal Micro Drill press - Bosch IXO, Dremel, Makita,. (Mini-Standbohrer)

description.text:
ModulIX-O is a tiny but solid and complete screw less Drill-press.
I was looking for a smart solution to make precise holes in small parts. So I decided to do this one. I wanted a solution that don't need to use screws or any other shopping parts.
I use an IXO and a Dremel, so one of my goals was that it should fit both ^^
It is completely modular, to be flexible for new devices too. A vice will be added soon. See it in Action here: http://www2.pic-upload.de/img/29391162/output_oOBSxI.gif It works, but iam still working on it. If you have issues, feel free to message me, i will try to fix it. All you need is a good calibrated Printer and maybe 3 compression springs. Features:
  • Auto Switch on/off (needs 1 compresion spring)
  • Auto lift up (needs 2 compression springs)
  • Screw less (& all parts printed, except springs)
  • Modular ( highly customizable )
    • greetz

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.3 mm

Infill:

min. 50% +

Notes: The "Y Carrier" is tricky to print, it's the most important part. Be sure that it gets printed clean and accurate! Maybe it needs a little to be filed inside. The Base parts should be glued together for better stability.
I recommend to print all parts with a really high infill level. Auto Lift-Up & Auto on:
Depending on your spring length, you should cut the Tubes to fit your springs,

author: FunkyArt

description.text:
Yet another case for the electronics. Please note that this is a work in progress. My take on this will be a screw-less assembly with optional mount for a fan. I will try to make it as parametric as possible. 2011-10-20: I decided to upload the models done so far even though I have not yet verified printing them.
Images of the parts will be uploaded as I have verified prints. I have yet to figure out a good way to design the top of the case.
I want it to have openings for the stepper/term/endstop contacts so that they can be connected without opening the case but I'm not sure that will be easy to print as a single part. Suggestions welcome. Files intended for printing:
bottom.scad : The bottom part of the case.
sides.scad : The sides of the case.
printer_mount.scad : The MakerGear Prusa Mendel mount. Files used by the printable models:
parameters.scad : The parameters for the case. Used by all files.
ramps.scad : Layout of the electronics and used for alignment and cut-outs on the sides. Used in sides.scad
grid.scad : Helper module for creating a grid pattern. Used in bottom.scad and printer_mount.scad. Other files:
case.scad : The composite case. Mostly for illustration and alignment verification. 2011-10-24: Uploaded images of my first print and updated models somewhat due to alignment.
Changes to the models include
  • positions and dimensions of the electronics
  • positions of the arduino mount plugs
  • dimension bottom part mount interface
  • corner plug hole height
    I had to widen the hole for the arduino USB contact as I was not able to slide the electronics into place.
    The cross shaped opening on the bottom part had to be widened as it was not possible to attach the bottom part to the printer mount.
    The corner plugs were too high to fit into the corner holes.
    The plugs for the arduino board turned out too thin as they broke off - I will probably drill holes for nut-and-bolts.

The models have not been centered so depending on your setup you may need to adjust this before printing. Depending on your tuning of the printer the mount pins for the arduino board may end up bad so you may want to adjust their size or do away with them entirely in favor of bolt holes.
The same goes for the bottom corner pins used for assembling the sides part. As for the placement of the mount pins you may want to verify alignment before printing - I think I did a good enough job but no guarantees.
The same goes for the electronics cut-outs. The bottom part has a cross shaped cut-out that should match the cross shaped extrusion on the printer mount. This is intended for snap-on of the case to the printer mount.
Another Morph of Punk Girl...

author: Drezt

title: HicTop Prusa i3 Auto Bed Leveling Sensor Mount

description.text:
This is a sliding mount for the auto bed leveling sensor type SN04-N used on some Prusa i3 3D printers. This sliding mount is much easier to adjust than fixed mounts and is easy to make from commonly available screws. You will need a 1.375" long 4-40 screw and a 4-40 nut to create the lead screw. The mount is screwed to the bearing block using 4mm cap screws. The sensor is screwed to the sliding portion using the original 3mm screws and nuts. This mount can be adjusted by very small amounts making it easier to get your Z height just right for the perfect first layer. The design can be adapted to other printers by doing a new base mount for the base and sliding parts which stay the same. For convenience I added another members sliding portion design for 12 and 18mm round sensors. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1354218 In the Files section of this Thing I have placed a PDF document giving details about how to assemble and install this sliding mount. I designed this sensor mount using TinkerCAD. I'm an amateur designer so I did a seat of the pants design. I did allow some clearance between the slide and the mount but depending the printer used to make the part, that clearance may or may not be enough. This is why I suggest to sand the part for a perfect fit. Here is access to the part in TinkerCAD so that you can look at it.
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/a8XgNPFI4O6-30mmslidingconnectorv3
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4qAJbcP2OjP-30mmslidingbasev3
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/acEVQB3GHT9-30mmslidebearing-block-mountv3 Update: Some people are finding that their sensors are not reliable when powered with 5V . I've attached a circuit that I use that allows the sensor to be powered with a higher voltage such as 12 - 24 V and lowers the output signal to 0-5 V for the input to the controller. It uses a blocking diode. When the sensor output is 12-24 V, the diode blocks the voltage so that the controller input is 5 V. When the sensor output goes to 0 V, the diode conducts and the controller input is pulled to nearly 0 V (actually 0.7 V).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

40%

Notes: Black PLA
extruder 195c
bed 55c on Kapton You will need to do a little sanding to get a smooth sliding action. At least I did on my printer. After you get the slide and base working smoothly, screw the 4-40 nut and the screw to the base. Add a tiny drop of Super glue to the threads and screw the nut so there is no clearance and the screw turns smoothly. Be careful to not get glue on the hole in the base.The bearing block is super glued to the back side of the fixed slide part. Make sure the two cap screw holes are visible(not blocked). The glued assembly is then screwed to the bearing mount using two 4mm cap screws. Attach the sensor to the sliding portion with two 3mm screws and nuts. The nuts fit in the recessed back side of the slide. Insert the slide part into the base and turn the screw until the slide is all the way into the base. The slide is self threading and after a few in and out runs will work great.

title: Webcam Bed Mount - Makerfarm Prusa i3v

description.text:
A mount for a webcam which attaches directly to the print bed. This way the webcam moves with the print bed, making for high-quality streaming/timelaspes. I love Octoprint's webcam view feature, but it can be tough to see what is going on with the print is moving around.
This was designed for my 8"x12" extended print bed, but I think the bed shape for the 10" and 12" print beds are around the same design. This will NOT fit the stock 8"x8" print bed, as the corners have a completely different design.
There are two version: one with an arm that is used to clip it to the print bed and help stabilize it, and one without that arm. I have not personally tried one without the arm, but the mount seems pretty solid. If you use that one, please let people know in the comments!

Printer:

Makerfarm Prusa i3v

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

10%

Notes: I printed it in ABS, but PLA should work as well: It is printed on its side so that supports aren't needed. If you are printing the version with the arm, be sure to turn on a cooling fan so that the overhangs turn out nicely.

I designed this using Onshape, a free, browser-base CAD software. I have made it public, so sign up for a free Onshape.com account, and visit the link below. Feel free to make a copy of it, and change it to suit your print bed! https://cad.onshape.com/documents/a4dc2377448845f2b3154a10/

comments.text: I've tried the version without the arm on a MakerFarm Pegasus, which works fine. I have an aluminium bed, so I created a version of the mount to fit the 3mm thickness.

author: carrer

title: FPV Groundstation in a Beauty Case

description.text:
This project is still in work! A while ago I built an antennatracker based on the open360tracker project using their original components (http://fpv-community.de/showthread.php?49179-open360tracker-Der-Community-Antennentracker-Made-in-Germany) But after having it in operation for some months, I got tired of the assembly and disassembly. Bolting it on a tripod, connecting separate battery, etc. and also the necessity of a separate transport case was very annoying. So I purchased a cheap beauty case, removed the foldable trays that were inside and designed a few new components. The top cover is supposed to be cut from 6mm plywood, the dome that carries the rotating part of the tracker from 4mm plywood.
The other parts can be printed, but I have to say, that I had to do some manual rework before they fitted together nicely. Might be my printer, might be too small tolerances in design. Let me know, if you want it to be perfect, I can share my raw files. The target is to have an one-in-all groundstation that includes the tracker, a Li-Ion battery, video-splitter and a couple of output connectors which can be individually switched on and off, connectors for charger and external power supply (just in case...), low battery buzzer, etc. pp. and in the bottom a socket to just plug it on the spigot of a lighting stand.

This set of models is inspired by one of my favorite games of all time, Man o' War, which is sadly long out of print. If you are lucky enough to have access to a set of rules for this game, these model could function as adequate proxies. The real lead goes for astronomical prices on eBay. If you're curious, you can learn more about the game here: The Sea of Claws The models aren't particularly detailed, as they were designed to print on my old Prusa Mendel, which would struggle to reproduce sub-millimeter details. Its been years since I looked at these files. so I thought it was time to share them with the world. I hope I didn't miss any. This are all modeled from scratch, inspired by long out of print commercial miniatures. No infringement of the original designers IP is intended. These are unofficial and not intended to compete with the real product in any way. In fact, nothing would thrill me more than for these models to inspire enough interest to justify bringing the game back into print so we can all spend our hard-earned money on it! If any copy-write holder takes offence to this work, please let me know! *One of the photos of painted minis were done my Shaun A. He did a really nice job of showing off how good they can look. I used the photo without his consent... I hope he doesn't mind!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: I believe that all of these should be printable without support, and there is support model in where needed. The Hulk may not be right, I think it should have support, or needs to be printed in parts - the files for which I can't track down just now, but I'll keep looking.

Some parts are designed to be warmed and reshaped after printing, hopefully it's obvious which.  
Some have built in support that will need to be removed / cleaned up.  
Some are in multiple pieces and require assembly.
Bases for flying units are not included.  
I used dowel/tooth picks/skewers for masts and paper for sails - you'll need to work that out on your own.

Wire Guide
This is a great wire guide that organize the messy wires especially those behind the computer desk. It's made to fit table with 1" or 2.5cm thick. I always wanted to organize my wires but I can't really find anything from that store that does what I wanted. I wanted something big enough to hold several cables and easy to install. Screwing and nailing is hard in tight spaces and making changes is a pain. So, I decided to design one for myself. After many versions of trial and errors, I finally came up with a version that fit my need.
1) No screws, nails or tapes are needed. You can still do it to make it more permanent.
2) Easy to install - especially in those tight spaces, like behind the table against the wall?
3) Simple to print and fast. Who have an hour to print one guide? Chances are you may need to print more than one guide. I printed 6 in about an hour.
4) Fit nicely - I made the slot that goes into the table with 1 degree inward for each clamp.
5) Use less PLA. So, I made it with holes. The cable will not fall through those holes, I promise! ** Adjust the clamps to fit the thickness of your desk/table. Mine is exactly 1" or 2.5 cm. Have Fun!

description.text:
Spreadsheet based tool to help convert Diamond Weight in carats to Girdle Diameter in mm for various cut shapes using best fit lines based on average diamond dimensions found here http://d.neadiamonds.com/diamond-carat Potentially very useful when combined with the following:
Ring metal cost calculator http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12589
Ring Creation Script http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12448
Ring Size System Coversion http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12689
for costing a custom engagement ring or other such tomfoolery.

0.Open the spreadsheet in Excel or Openoffice or whatever.
  • Choose the line on the graph corresponding to the type of diamond cut you want e.g. Asscher
  • Left click to select the line of interest, then right click and select "Add Trendline" to try to fit a curve to the data.
  • In the "Add Trendline" window choose a line type (power is good for round cuts), make sure to display the "Equation" and "R-squared" value on the graph
  • Check the curve matches the data points on the graph reasonably well and that the R-squared value is very high (99%+), if not go back and choose another line type in the "Add Trendline" window.
  • Use equation to convert your carat weight to girdle dimensions, remembering for some cut shapes (e.g. Emerald & Oval) you may need to do this for a major and minor axis
    • Beware that this is just a rough guide, every jewel will be different. So if possible double-check sizes before getting an item manufactured by a goldsmith etc.

Since I own a Orion Delta from SeeMeCNC, my heating resistors burn through twice and needed to be replaced (which needed some soldering). Also I planned on putting some LEDs next to my hot-end. Therefor rewiring and soldering every time was quite a pain in the a.. . That is why I decided to use some quick wiring solutions put on top of the printing head. The result can be seen in the pictures. The model contains a ground plate with two slides for two wire clips, soldered on a 10 by 20.8 mm plate.
It also contains a holder for the wires coming from the base and a cut-out for the wires going down to the hot-end. the second part is a cap to cover all the wires and give a nice clean look in the end. For attaching the plate to the print-head, the already existing screws on the center plate have to be unscrewed and replaced by longer versions. Unfortunately the screws does not have a metric size. However, M3 Screws and nuts seem to work fine.

title: Brackets for upcycled Lack table enclosure

description.text:
Table leg extensions/retainers for upcycled lack table enclosure.
Instructions here: http://www.instructables.com/id/3d-Printer-Enclosure-from-Upcycled-Furniture/?ALLSTEPS NOTICE: When moving a printer to a heated enclosure, any parts that will be subjected to stress must be heat resistant. The first time I put my Makerfarm i3v into an enclosure the included extruder warped as it was made of PLA. Make sure you have ABS parts! Just a quick video of the enclosure:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qyo_cYV6BXk Update : it's been almost a year since I started to use this enclosure. The printer is now more of a piece of furniture rather than a small appliance. It is absolutely fantastic. I print almost exclusively in ABS and I have virtually no problems with warping or separating layers. I have heatsinks on the steppers and the electronics are moved out of the enclosure. It gets up to about 55C inside.

comments.text: How much long is the extender?
comments.author: AnakinO7

comments.text: How much more space does this give? Would I be able to easily make it taller if I needed? Sorry if this is a basic question I'm new to 3D printing.
comments.author: Kalebbroo

comments.text:
Try this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1418719
comments.author: Kalebbroo

comments.text: Oh, one more hint. If you are using the i3v printer with a stock extruder or you have made any modifications using PLA,  be sure to reprint them in ABS! The increased temperatures causes PLA to warp under stress. My original makerfarm extruder was PLA and warped in the first print.
comments.author: Kalebbroo

comments.text: Sorry to take so long to reply. There is about 2" clearance above my i3v 8". I'm doing my yearly teardown and rebuild and will post some pictures with measurements. I suppose the easiest way to make them taller is to scale the z-axis up. I made it in sketchup but I don't know if I still have the files. I'll post it if I find it.
comments.author: Kalebbroo

comments.text: How big are the screw holes?
comments.author: daKEEBLERelf

comments.text: 3mm. I just used basic multipurpose construction screws from the hardware store to secure it to the table.
comments.author: daKEEBLERelf

comments.text: How is the top table secured? the four holes in the printed part? or is the top table just resting on the spacers?
comments.author: archprlest

comments.text: It just rest on top of the spacers. I've been using the enclosure for a couple weeks now and I love it.
comments.author: archprlest

comments.text: Does the plexiglass hold it in place well? I took your design and shrunk it by 10 mm but have two kids and wife the might bump it and just wonder if it would hold.  Live the brackets as I needed more space for my printer to fit.
comments.author: Zen1

comments.text: I posted a video in the description.
comments.author: archprlest

comments.text: I think it would be difficult to just bump over. You could probably reinforce it with velcro or adhesive. I have things on top of it and I think in order to strike it with enough force for it to tip over, the entire tower would go with it. The dimensions are pretty tight and it is a snug fit. Come to think of it, you could probably just use some duct tape on the insides of the table legs if you really wanted to be sure. I like that I can lift the top table straight off for maintenance. I'm currently using rigid 1/2 in foam insulation instead of plexiglass due to cost. I put a thermocouple inside and when I'm printing with ABS and a 100C bed, it will hit about 45-50C inside. I'll take a video and upload it tonight of me beating on it.
comments.author: archprlest

Trying to print in Bridge Nylon which delaminates awfully on the print bed. This cover will mitigate draughts and I will also try drying filament in the oven prior to printing. Made with Lexan available from Home Depot and Lowes in USA. Other plastics will work but Lexan cuts well with a circular saw - do not try with a plastic cutter, clamp the lexan securely when cutting and DO wear goggles. You need 4 inner and outer corners, and 14 inner and outer edge brackets which fit on the identical front and back covers. Each are 3" deep to clear the traversing print bed and are free standing. Lexan clamps hook under the printer frame to secure the top, left and right covers. Note before deciding where these clamps go make sure you closely watch the print head drive assembly movements especially when it goes through its initial homing routine. You need to keep the back left corner of the top cover clear of clamps especially or you will foul on this assembly. All brackets/clamps secured with #6 x 1/2" self tapping screws. For the Lexan I got most of the pieces out a 28 x 30 x .093 sheet but for the two top bits I had to buy another smaller sheet . See jpg for how I cut up sheets. Also see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1654725 for my later addition of a filament guide that mnimizes gap and hence down draughts from above print head.
All clamps and brackets modeled in AutoDesk Inventor

comments.text: Can you suggest how many clamps one should print? I'm starting to get the parts printed and would like to make sure I'm not waiting on a print half way through assembly.
comments.author: ttabbal

comments.text: 18-20 is enough.   READ my caution on making sure you do not foul the drives with clamps -esp on top cover.
comments.author: ttabbal

comments.text: Thanks for the info. I'm printing the last batch and getting ready to cut the plastic sheet. I'll be extra careful with the clamp positions to make sure I don't mess up the areas the X-axis needs to move in.

comments.text: Yep - I don't fuss too much on orientation when 3D modeling, reckoning it is easy to spin on the slicer software prior to printing.

description.text: this is a 1:10 scale rc car sand board to help you get out of the mud with your rc crawler in a scale crawl.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300microns

Infill:

2%

Notes: you should print it in pla and at 300 microns. you could do it in abs but it is better in pla because it is more flexable.

Landing Gear for a 250 Racing Quadcopter like ZMR 250, QAV 250 or other, simply use a screw to mount them under each arm. It will lift the quadcopter a little bit off the ground and keeps most of the mud away from the bottom-plate. They are shorter than the normal legs that come with an ZMR250 and will pop off in a hard crash. Any 2.5 to 3 mm screw with a lenght at least 5mm plus the thickness of the arm will fit.  It weights less than 4g printed with PLA. No support, no raft, 2 shells, no fill used and 0.2mm layer height. This is something you loose once in a while, so PLA is your eco-friendly choice.
V3.2: Stronger Sphere, older Version was a bit thin for rough flying...

comments.text: This is an excellent design that meets my needs to a tee!  I don't like to haul any unnecessary, extra weight around and these are perfect with a weight of about 4.5 g for 4 including the mounting screw ( I used an SAE #4 @ about 6-7mm length).  The screws cut a thread in the arm, so all you have to do is twist another landing foot in place when they get damaged.  I printed them in ABS with a layer height of 0.3.  I broke off the top of one in a controlled crash onto concrete, but I'll use a soldering iron and a bit of filament and weld it back on.  I'll print a couple sets next time.

title: Track connecting pins for Tank Tracks

description.text: Using steel M3 x 45 bolts and nuts appeared unnecessary, especially as they are expensive and hard to get in USA.  1/8" bolts in a similar length were equally elusive.  I modeled these pins and they are a very tight fit in the track pieces.  Once in I pushed on the "nuts" and glued them in place.  Haven't tried yet as I haven't finished printing the sprockets, working out what I am doing for bearings or ordered the servos.  However I have no reason to think these plastic pins won't be fit for purpose.
Downloaded from Inventor content center.  Note the threads are just a graphical representation by the looks of it - when exported to STL you just get a plain pin.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dNdRjksUHDY I had just watched the new Star Wars movie before it officially came out in U.S. with my freind, Bailey N. we knew it was a great way to introduce the franchise again. When I got home I had wondered if any one had made a working light saber but NOPE. So that point went start making a really bad looking nonfunctional prototype. Over time Bailey came online and decided to make a model different in the since it has the look of the current one. Now it looks like his model but functions how the toy ones work with the slide out :)

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 PLA Model

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

.25%

Notes:

  • Lightsaber blades print better with rafts and also, make sure there is no support material on the laser parts. Laser parts print at 2 mm PERIMETERS LAYERS

  • The hilt will be glued to together when then laser parts are inserted properly. support material is needed in some small areas... the 2 nubs on the back need it.. bottom of the hilt on the rounded part that just floats there needs it...most importantly the square stub on the side needs support.
    • Now if you read that and was confused by nubs and stubs and other things i wouldn't blame you.

Proto Pasta Carbon is awesome and makes great smooth prints. But the prints do not look like carbon fiber or have the strength. This is a file to create a woven carbon fiber mat from Proto Pasta Carbon that can be used as a material itself. It does seem to be very strong but will still tear easily along the ribbons if you are not careful. Im sure you will be aware this is not 'real' carbon fiber...but its not bad and looks good!
The mat can be thermo moulded by heating with hot water. The two tubes shown were made this way. A heat gun and a template might produce better results. Alternatively you can use the attached sketchup file and 'cut' out the shape you want; You can also layer up to any thickness you want. I would love to see all your results!. Printing the mat is actually really hard as you need to get the Proto Pasta to flow and weave rather than bridge or break. I print at 220 centigrade, really slow at 500 mm/min with an extrusion multiplier of 1.5/1.6; this matt actually takes half an hour to print. No retraction, No infill. The slice thickness that works for me is 0.075mm. The file is actually made with 2.5mm wide ribbons and a ribbon height of 0.1mm. For a 0.5 mm nozzle no changes are required if you print at 0.1mm slice thickness. For a 0.4mm nozzle scale x and y at 96%. For a 0.075mm slice thickness scale z at 75%. The basic premise is that you need to ensure ribbon height equals slice height and there is no infill, this is so the fibers are laid in one axis only for each weave layer. Ill try and make other weaves if I get the chance.
Let me know how you get on.

description.text:
The Mars Community Pods The Pods: What you see here is an idea for a modular Mars habitat/space station manufactured to a set size for any individual countries or pioneers. These units have self leveling legs to adjust to the varying elevation of the planet'?s surface, leveling the pod as well as protecting the planet'?s surface and leaving a small footprint. The dome surrounding the habitat(s) acts as a clear (see through) solar protection from the planets harsh solar rays, varying temperatures, weather, and is also a solar generator. Inside The Pods: Inside these pods you'?ll see different habitats such as laboratories (for the study of life on mars), aquaponics (for food production such as fruits and vegetables, as well as fishing), an orchard/forest (consisting of different fruit, nuts, oxygen for atmosphere, space for exercise, and different entomology for pollination), and custom home of your very own design can be erected inside of the pods for the comforts of your home on Mars.
Any necessary pods can be added for different purposes such as: Waste management, Central power pod (Power regulation between all pods, and to create new energy possibilities), Water pod (Research in possible water production and usage), etc. (The hole in the pods are just to see inside, actual pod does not include hole)

author: Jammydoger

description.text:
This spreadsheet will allow you to do a somewhat more apples-to-apples comparison of the value of metal used in a ring before you of to get it made. It doesn't take into account extra manufacturing costs but should give you a ballpark estimate of the raw material cost so you can make sure you aren't getting ripped off etc. Potentially very useful when combined with the following:
Ring Creation Script http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12448
Diamond size shape weight conversion Spreadsheet http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12586
Ring Size System Coversion http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12689
for costing a custom engagement ring or other such tomfoolery. Contains data for the following metals with Spot prices as of 2011-October-14 24kt Pure gold
950 Palladium
950 Platinum
Fine Silver
Tungsten
Titanium
Rhodium
Copper
Nickel
Zinc
18kt Red Gold (75Au 25Cu) Est.
18kt White Gold (75Au 25Pt) Est.
18kt White Gold (75Au 25Pd) Est.
18kt White Gold (75Au 10Pd 10Ni 5Zn) Est.
14kt White Gold (58Au ~42Ar)**
Sterling Silver (92.5Ar 7.5Cu) Est. Est. => Estimated minimum cost based constituent metal cost, actual cost is likely to be higher as the metals will have to be processed etc. to create the desired alloy
  • Not suitable as a ring material for allergy, strength etc. reasons but may be used as an alloying metal
    **Actual 14kt White Gold Ni/Pd free formula is more like (58Au 40Ar 1.5Tin 0.5Ge) but hard to get prices for Germanium so assume it doesn't massively affect material cost due to its low concentration and presence of very low cost Tin
    • Sources
    http://money.cnn.com/data/commodities/
    http://www.coinnews.net/tools/live-silver-gold-platinum-spots/
    xe.com
    http://www.metalprices.com/
    http://www.csgnetwork.com/specificgravmettable.html
    http://www.reade.com/Particle_Briefings/spec_gra.html
    http://www.clihouston.com/knowledge-base/composition-of-gold-alloys.html

• Open Spreadsheet in OpenOffice, Excel, whatever.
  • Input the day's metal spot prices into the "metal pound cost [US$/0.454kg]" or "metal troy ounce cost [US$/0.031kg]" columns (links to sites used to find these are provided)
  • Input the basic dimensions of your ring (Internal Diameter, Wall Thickness, Height or Depth, Feature Size)in [mm]
    3a. Use one of the 4 provided ring cross sectional shapes (Rectangle, Ellipse, Pill shaped, Half ellipse) to estimate comparative metal value
    OR
    3b. Create a column for your own custom shape and calculate the Cross Sectional Area, Circumference through centre of area and Rough Volume to generate a new column of estimate comparative metal value data
  • Being forewarned and forearmed, you can now approach a metalsmith and choose a ring material with more confidence.

comments.text: It seems like this would be a great addition to any program that generates a model.  Just plug in material costs.  The slicers generally know how much material they're going to use, so it could give you a parts cost immediately.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Indeed, I see it mostly being of use to prevent people (especially me) being fooled due to their ignorance of the cost of materials in products they are buying/making.

description.header: Project:  Fry's First 100 Sight Words Rubbing Plates
description.text: Objectives These are rubbing plates to allow kids to use a crayon or pencil to transfer the words onto a piece of paper. Audiences This is geared towards grade school as the significant other is a Kindergarten teacher. Preparation In addition to the plates you will need a piece of paper and a crayon or pencil. Steps Place paper on top of plate covering the word you want to transfer. Then rub your crayon or pencil lightly over the whole word until it appears. Results The significant others students have had a blast identifying the words on the small test plates I made. After trying out a few different letter heights and fonts, this is the design she decided on.

author: thelittlepilot2002

description.text: This is a replacement batter cover for a Python 7251P 2-way remote. It does also fit the one-way remote (7652P) that came with the starter as well. Anyone with these remotes knows that the battery covers break off very easily. So just print a replacement! This should also work on other Python remotes with the same shell (7153P, 7152P) but I don't have them to be sure. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9KnKnMF8Bzt

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: I recommend printing this on a slower speed as the tabs that hook into the remote are small and will not cool in time with a faster print speed. I printed in both PLA and Colorfabb XT and they both will work just fine for this.

I used my calipers to measure every part of the existing remote as well as the broken battery cover.  However, given the resolution of the printer I needed to do some trial and error in order to work within the tolerances of the remote.  This isn's a perfect match, of course, bit it makes a nice tight fit. 
Given the design, however, this will probably be just as fragile as the original ... so I'll just print another!

title: Modified Rostock Bowden Clamp for 1.75mm and MakerGear Hotends w/Zipties

description.text:
I wanted a version of the ziptie bowden clamp in 1.75mm that would fit the Makergear hotend. For added support I also wanted an M4 nut socket on the extruder side clamp for added support. Of all the ones uploaded up here there wasn't one that had all the features I needed:
  • MakerGear Compatible
  • 1.75mm Filament
  • Zipties
  • M4 nut socket on extruder clamp
  • Rostock platform
    • The 3mm version I remixed this from had almost everything so I was able to modfity it in openSCAD with the help of a friend. I would have started with the 1.75mm version up here but it did not include the OpenSCAD file so I had to work with the 3mm version to make mine. I've uploaded it here so that others can make use of it!

Version 4.0 of the Public Lab smartphone spectrometer. This spectrometer is a scientific tool that straps onto an Android or iOS phone, tablet, or any camera capable of focusing very close (macro-mode) and allows you to collect spectra. Why would you want one? You can use it to identify the elemental composition of things (light bulbs, olive oil, beer, etc) based on the colors of light they emit. You can even use it to monitor your home brewing progress (http://bit.ly/Xyor6B). This is a HUGE upgrade from the previous versions. The wall are thicker, it has a tripod mount, and the entrance slit can accommodate clip-on accessories. We originally started making these changes to optimize the model for injection molding but they work great for 3D printing as well. You can order one on Shapeways (http://shpws.me/oHcZ), and there is also a papercraft version available here: http://store.publiclab.org/products/foldable-mini-spectrometer CAUTION: Portions of this model were optimized for injection molding so this is definitely a difficult print to get right. Make sure your printer is tuned well before starting.

Assembly is much easier than earlier models.
  • Print the three parts (the base and two body pieces, basically all the STLs)
  • Attach a film grating to the upper side of the base (double-sided tape works well)
  • Either screw the two body pieces together or glue them if you want a permanent bond. Attach the base using four screws.
  • Mount it to your phone
  • Use spectralworkbench.org to calibrate, save, and share your spectra. (If you use an iDevice then the opera browser seems to work best)
    • If you use an extrusion printer such as a Mendel you will probably need to print with support if you want the text to show up. If anybody wants a version without the text, let me know and I will post it as soon as I am able. Also, make sure you have your printer tuned up to print bridges and overhangs very well, because this thing is basically one huge overhang. I have successfully printed it on a MendelMax. All parts have been NetFabbed and verified.
    This is the grating I have used for the prototype. It is the linear style with 1000lines per mm: tinyurl.com/9tjrz8r . You can also use the film off of a CD, DVD, or BluRay as seen here: publiclaboratory.org/tool/spectrometer

description.text: UPDATE:Now added a new version that is a little cleaner and fixes a couple small normally unnoticeable kinks with the current one. Hope you enjoy!

This is my solution to auto bed leveling, I tried to make it as simple as possible. I have not run it through my own personal tests which is why I have it listed as work in progress. as you can see you need 4 springs (can probably get away with 3), I used springs from a spring assortment kit you can buy at home depot (if I remember correctly it is found in the door hardware area). Essentially this allows you to swap out almost anything on your hot end or your hot end entirely and not have to once touch marlin or any settings. you would set the zprobe offset to the distance between the set screw (upwards facing screw below the switch) and the switch in the pressed position. once that offset is set, unless you adjust the set screw you should be able to swap out any hot end and not have to reconfigure. The switch I used was this one from radioshack ( I was surprised to find one still open around me): https://www.radioshack.com/products/spdt-switch-without-roller?variant=5717496645 Other switches might fit and if not it shouldn't be hard to remix this for another switch.
once you have the switch installed it gets wired as shown in this article: http://reprap.org/wiki/Mechanical_Endstop Any suggestions please let me know, I am always looking to improve my printer. The screws used are: (3x) 3 mm x 16 mm
(2x) 2.5 mm x 16 mm
(3) 3 mm x 24 mm
and 3 appropriately sized springs and associated nuts **Edit: short video of it in action! https://youtu.be/l_VesPKXz7g
UPDATE: longer video of my printer auto leveling and then printing the cute Octopus: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FUAceB9UwOI UPDATE 9/8/16: I have uploaded the version of marlin I am using, I don't remember of the top of my head what modifications I have made to this version for different projects. So use at your own risk, I always advise checking that the safety features you want (ie watchdog ect.) are enabled

comments.text: I have had no issues with ringing, echoing or the hot end wiggling. The hot end is very stable, that being said if you keep your springs too loose it wont be stable so make sure that they are tightened down enough to prevent moving during normal operations but allow proper auto leveling. Do not over tighten the springs either or you will have issues finding the proper Z-offset to account for the distance traveled prior to the switch being actuated. I personally keep the front spring (the one across from the switch) tighter than the other two as to cause it to slightly pivot at that point ensuring the the force from touching the bed is directed to the switch consistently instead of pivoting away from the switch causing a further distance to be traveled. I set my springs when I first put it together and haven't had to adjust them since to give you an idea of reliability. I also disassembled my printer (just slid the top and bottom off of the towers to take up less space) so I could pack it up for moving to a new house and just quickly put it back together at the new location and didn't have to do any recalibration to start printing again at the same quality and reliability.

title: AG GoPro Hero3/4 Armour
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
GoPro protection on multirotors has been something I've been experimenting on since breaking my first Hero3 on my miniquad. This lead me to make my youtube video on how to mod the stock housing, which was praised and used by FPV Pilots such as Metalldanny. https://youtu.be/KxhskpvpH8s I decided to design a 3D printed version... The AG GoPro Armour features:
  • lined inside with craft foam
  • the width of the armour is the same as the gopro, so it can fit in gopro cages of existing miniquad frames (such as the MB Epic and Hovership Zuul
  • the buttons are protected from being hit or pressed accidently
  • a standard gopro lense protector can be used
    • NOTES:
  • use an adhesive back craft foam to line the inside of the armour. Use this or something similiar http://www.michaels.com/creatology-value-pack-adhesive-foam-sheets/10104248.html?productsource=PDPZ1
  • the GoPro will fit inside the armour with friction from the foam. A velcro strap can be used to secure the armour onto the GoPro. Use this or something similiar http://www.michaels.com/velcro-brand-one-wrap-straps/10218638.html#q=velcro&start=21
  • in some mounting scenarios, I don't use the velcro strap, because the gopro cage of your miniquad will have its own velcro strap to hold the GoPro (and armour) to the frame.
  • on your miniquad gopro cage frame, use the same craft foam to line where it will make contact with the AG GoPro Armour. It will give it extra support, dampen vibration and keep the Armour from sliding.
  • because the buttons are protected and recessed inside the AG GoPro Armour, use a stylus or other rounded pointing device to access and press the buttons.
  • when cutting the foam, press the foam onto the Armour and cut along the indents
  • a curved lexan scissor works well to cut curves in the foam
  • a hole puncher works well to cut out circles in the foam

FREE VERSION for my design is ALWAYS available here...
But if you want to contribute back to the design, you can visit Pinshape https://pinshape.com/items/16172-3d-printed-ag-gopro-34-armour

New design added! NEW design uploaded: AG GoPro Vest I've been playing with an alternative variation to the originally uploaded "armour" design. The "vest" was actually the original design, but took much longer to tweak it just right. I wanted a lense hood to act as protector (instead of using the stock lense protector). Laser cut cardboard, Elmer's glue, and an Ikea Hemma light bulb fixture and cord set make up this egg-shaped cardboard lamp.
The Ellipsoid-SVG and Ellipsoid-EPS zip files each contain the 21 (svg or eps file-format, respectively) laser cutter files necessary to cut all the layers for the lamps. Sheets 1-8 each contain 3 rings; sheet 9 contains 2 rings; and sheets 10-21 each contain a single ring. The cutting process will yield 38 cardboard rings.

The diameters for each cardboard ring was calculated using SphereGen.exe from my spherical cardboard lamp tutorial. The bottom half of this lamp is simply half of a sphere, while the top half is a section of a "sphere" from it's midpoint to three-fourths-point where the sphere was effectively stretched by entering a smaller "cardboard thickness" value into the calculation than the actual cardboard used. E.g., to produce a spheroid that is twice as tall as it is wide, enter a cardboard thickness that is half of what it actually is. So, if each layer of your cardboard is 0.17 inches thick, enter 0.085 into SphereGen.exe.

comments.text: hello nice work how thick is the cardboard ?
comments.author: bengee

comments.text: The cardboard I used was 0.17 inches thick. I recommend stacking 10 pieces, measuring them all together, then dividing by 10 to get the average thickness since it is difficult to accurately measure such a small amount.

description.text:
This plastic part enables you to mount a TR8X2 threaded rod on your 3drag/k8200 printer.
You can find a very cheap trapezoidal threaded rod kit on aliexpress.com typing "thsl-400-8d".
There are 2 versions:
V1: You need only self-tapping screws to lock the fz0012 nut on the printed part.
V2: You need only M3 screws and nuts to lock the fz0012 nut on the printed part.
If you decide to use a TR8X2 threaded rod don't forget to set "steps per mm" to Z:400.

author: wpns

description.text: I added and external antenna to my Wii U.  This goes on a vertically standing unit, near the back corner, on top of the fan and USB ports. USB ports are still fully usable.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Smartrap

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Flip it 180 on Y axis so the back flat part is laying flat. Without rafts, this part comes out nice and smooth. I added my own supports, circular tubes, that have .35mm walls, at .2mm layers, my printer was extruding at .35mm wide. I tend to have issues with supports that are too close to the main structure, they tend to fuse and makes taking off a pain. Since the object is flat, then support is needed for the antenna holder section. The support structures didn't need support, but the flat part did. Also, the opening for the rubber feet, which gets used to anchor the whole unit to the Wii U, needed support. Make sure you change your minimum perimeters though, or a single walled .35mm tube will turn into a cylinder. Otherwise this will make a very thin support that will come right off using an xacto knife. I recommend 100% infill. Took 2 hours to print on my slow as heck printer, but because I added a 15" 9dbi antenna, I wanted to make sure it would hold up to the stresses.

Antenna port side. You may or may not need to alter this depending on the antenna you use. Mine was 13.74mm thick, so I added a 14mm opening. This opening also allows use of a deep socket 8mm wrench bit, to mount the SMA nut. Depending on your need, you may be fine cutting out the entire front support lattice. DO NOT remove both front and back, the 45 degree ramps, as they are there to support for rotational torque on the SMA mount. If you choose a lower density or take out both supports, you may run the risk of the tab holding the antenna port, and thus the antenna, to just snap off.

I was trying to get an exact shape, but my kinect was picking it up weird, even after covering it with painters' tape.  So I traced an outline and used it as a reference image in blender.  Lots of calipers and a little patience.
